user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_set_enable:
```c
static void metal_softirq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *cntr,
				     int irq, unsigned int enable)
{
	if (irq < cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= (cntr->irq_base + cntr->irq_num)) {
		return;
	}

	irq -= cntr->irq_base;
	if (enable ==  METAL_IRQ_ENABLE) {
		atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 1);
	} else {
		atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 0);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_softirq_set_enable:
struct metal_irq_controller {
	int irq_base; /**< Start of IRQ number of the range managed by
		 	* the IRQ controller
		 	*/
	int irq_num; /**< Number of IRQs managed by the IRQ controller */
	void *arg; /**< Argument to pass to interrupt controller function */
	metal_irq_set_enable irq_set_enable; /**< function to set IRQ enable */
	metal_cntr_irq_register irq_register; /**< function to register IRQ
						* handler
						*/
	struct metal_list node; /**< list node */
	struct metal_irq *irqs; /**< Array of IRQs managed by the controller */
}
...
#define METAL_IRQ_ENABLE 1U
...

...

...

</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
atomic_store(&metal_softirq_enabled[irq], 1);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No — based on the provided code the atomic_store is not demonstrably dead. It updates metal_softirq_enabled[irq] when irq is in range and enable == METAL_IRQ_ENABLE; removing that store would change program behaviour if any other code reads that atomic flag to decide whether a softirq is enabled. Therefore, with the information given, Rule 2.2 is not violated (is_rule_violated: false).  (A concrete violation scenario would be: if throughout the whole project metal_softirq_enabled[] is never read or used — i.e. all accesses are only writes or the array is otherwise unused — then this atomic_store would be dead code and would violate Rule 2.2.)
